narrative.title: Xxx Corps - 1943Q2
narrative.situation: British Infantry Corps (mixed composition) deployed in North Africa during 1943Q2.
narrative.objectives: XXX Corps in Q2 1943 served as main infantry assault corps for final Eighth Army offensive operations in Tunisia. Corps mission: Break through heavily fortified Axis defensive lines using infantry-led set-piece assaults, enabling armoured exploitation by X Corps. Q2 saw two distinct phases: (1) Combat operations: Wadi Akarit assault (5-6 April 1943) where three divisions (4th Indian, 50th, 51st Highland totaling ~50,600 men) breached Axis defensive line forcing 240km retreat to Enfidaville. (2) Reorganization phase: Mid-April onward, XXX Corps dissolved/reorganized as Eighth Army prepared for Sicily invasion. Subordinate divisions transferred to other formations or withdrawn for rest.
narrative.axis_objective: Hold current positions and prevent Allied breakthrough.
narrative.allied_objective: Advance and neutralize Axis defensive positions.

weather.terrain: Southern Tunisia coastal sector: Wadi Akarit defensive line featured coastal plain, wadis, anti-tank ditches, rocky hills (Djebel Roumana, Djebel Fatnassa), and Axis fortifications. More varied terrain than Western Desert with better water availability.

special_rules: Three elite veteran divisions with extensive desert warfare experience
Strong artillery concentration (240× 25-pounder guns - 10 field regiments)
Specialized capabilities: Mountain warfare (4th Indian), night assault (51st Highland), breakthrough operations (50th)
Combined arms coordination: Infantry-artillery-engineer teams for fortified position assault
Mine clearance and breach operations expertise (proven at Mareth and Wadi Akarit)
Multi-national composition (British, Highland Scots, Indian, Gurkha) with proven cohesion
Heavy anti-tank gun deployment (24× 17-pounder guns - first operational use in North Africa)
